awd_titl_txt: Adaptive and disruptive epigenome-by-environment dynamics: molecular mechanisms to ecological impacts
awd_abstract_narration:
The developmental environment can have profound impacts on an individual. For example, in many non-mammalian vertebrates including some fish, most turtles, and all crocodilians, environmental temperatures occurring during a specific period of incubation will determine if individuals develop as either a male or female. Previous findings have revealed a critical role for the endocrine system and epigenetics, heritable changes in gene function without changes in DNA sequence, in determining how the environment impacts traits. This project will determine the mechanisms by which environments and hormone signaling act on epigenetic processes to shape developmental trajectories and produce phenotypic diversity. The project focuses on species displaying temperature-dependent sex determination, to address how temperature induces and coordinates radically different phenotypic trajectories. The study will support the training and mentoring of two graduate students and two undergraduate researchers, with recruiting efforts aimed at under-represented groups in the sciences. The project will develop a primer focused on communicating common misperceptions about epigenetics. The findings will be presented to students at area schools as part of an established outreach program. Together, this work will advance the understanding of the mechanisms that determine how organisms interact with the environments and will provide training opportunities for the next generation of scientists. 

The work will employ state of the art sequencing approaches to advance a developmental- and endocrine-based understanding of how adaptive epigenetic responses occur in nature, and how epigenetic responses are disrupted by environmental stressors for which a shared evolutionary history is absent. The Parrott Lab has previously observed widespread sexually dimorphic DNA methylation patterning across the gonadal genome. However, the developmental and molecular processes by which a bipotential genome acquires a sexually dimorphic epigenome is unclear. Developmental windows of environmental sensitivity will first be identified by resolving the temporal dynamics of the DNA methylome during temperature-dependent sex determination and reproductive development. Combinatorial treatments of temperature and hormones will then reveal the degree to which temperature and endocrine signals act on overlapping or distinct regions of the epigenome. Finally, the project will investigate the influence of environmental quality on the sexually dimorphic methylome. Given the inherent environmental sensitivity of temperature-dependent sex determination, it is hypothesized that environmental variables (other than temperature) also influence this process to affect the development and subsequent function of the reproductive system. Together, experiments will reveal how environmental and biological signals are integrated into developmental processes that result in phenotypic diversity. Findings from this work will be disseminated in peer-reviewed publications, presentations at national and international scientific, and more broadly via outreach activities in partnership with area schools.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Accomplishments: Components of the developmental environment interact with embryos to affect organismal form and function. In a striking example of this developmental plasticity, reproductive development is determined by temperature in many non-mammalian vertebrates including many fish, lizards, turtles, and crocodilians. For example, in the American alligator, the temperature experienced during a 23-28 day window dictates the expression of genetic pathways that lead to either the development of a testis or an ovary. During the course of this project, we studied the molecular mechanisms that govern these pathways and also how evolutionary processes modify these responses in different populations. 

 

We resolved which genes respond to temperature and which genes are under endocrine control using developmental profiling experiments at different temperatures along with treatments with exogenous steroid hormones. We found that genes involved in temperature dependent sex determination can be functionally and temporally grouped into those that first respond to incubation temperature and are insensitive to endocrine signaling (e.g., testosterone and estrogen), and those that respond to temperature later in development with their expression being modified by endocrine cues. Contrary to expectations, we found that estrogen signals, which are usually associated with ovarian development, are mostly involved in repressing the expression of testis-promoting genes rather than activating ovarian-promoting genes. We also examined the epigenetic mechanisms that are hypothesized to regulate the expression of genes involved in reproductive development. In particular, we found that DNA methylation patterning is dependent upon incubation temperature and corresponds with the expression of a subset of genes with temperature-dependent expression. Consistent with a role for DNA methylation in negatively regulating transcriptional activity, this subset of genes is enriched for regulation by the polycomb repressive complex 2 (PRC2). 

 

Finally, we sought to understand how temperature dependent responses vary across populations in the northern and southern extent of the alligator range. We found that genetic pathways (both expression and coding sequences) involved in temperature-dependent sex determination are more variable than those pathways unaffected by incubation temperature. Whereas the majority of genetic and regulatory variation were consistent with neutral evolutionary processes, several genes displayed signatures of selection. The expression of these genes is dependent on incubation temperature and population, and the coding sequences vary across northern and southern populations. These findings will be reported in a forthcoming manuscript. Ultimately, project findings have advanced our understanding of how environmental factors are integrated into molecular pathways to drive alternative phenotypic outcomes. 

 

Broader Impacts: The project supported the training of two graduate students and two undergraduate researchers, who were trained in field, molecular, and bioinformatic techniques. Additionally, the project supported outreach activities aimed at communicating concepts of developmental plasticity and epigenetics to middle school students. Using temperature dependent sex determination in alligators as an entry point, project personnel developed and implemented educational modules at local schools, which were supplemented by live animal demonstrations. Project personnel also communicated project goals and basic concepts at events geared towards the general public, including the Savannah Rive Ecology Laboratory’s Annual Science Saturday events. Results from nest temperature monitoring and forecasting efforts along with DNA methylome profiling were communicated to state and federal personnel tasked with alligator conservation and management at biannual Palmetto Alligator Research Symposium meetings and the IUCN’s Crocodilian Specialist Group meetings.
